docs.abstract: Kiran Continental and Indian Cuisine Restaurant, which serves Indian-Italian dishes at modest prices, open last month in midtown Manhattan; owner Ajid Saha comments (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Although Indian-Continental fusion cuisine is now popular, not all of it is expensive. Ajid Saha (pronounced SHA-ha) opened his modest Kiran Continental and Indian Cuisine at 401 West 53d Street at Ninth Avenue last month.

docs.abstract: Melanie S Katzmann letter on Taylor Holliday's April 10 travel article on Vietnam cuisine
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I have a recommendation for visitors to Vietnam who travel south of Ho Chi Minh City to the Mekong Delta. Directly across from the Cuu Long Hotel in Vinh Long is the Cuu Long restaurant, which features open-air dining over the Mekong River. Most of the river, and its commerce, is one thing to behold, but the food is another. I spent some time at the Cuu Long and in Vinh Long teaching English at the local university. Though I found many good restaurants, the Cuu Long is my favorite. It's far from fancy. But in the morning you can ask the staff to prepare something special for your evening dinner.

docs.lead_paragraph: A pro football strike and the absence of Monday Night Football was not what the Chilton Book Co. of Radnor, Pa., expected when it published ''The Monday Night Football Cookbook and Restaurant Guide'' on Oct. 1. The first printing was about 20,000 copies, according to Alan Turner, the company's editorial director.

docs.lead_paragraph: “The taste and the sense of smell form but one sense, of which the mouth is the laboratory and the nose the chimney,” wrote Jean-Anthelme Brillat-Savarin, the father of modern gastronomy. No American chef has taken Brillat-Savarin’s dictum to heart more quirkily than Grant Achatz, the chef at the restaurant Alinea in Chicago. He has made the use of pure scents — complementing the taste of food with items used for their smells alone — a hallmark of his inventive cuisine.

headline.main: Despair At the Top Of France's Food Chain

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: PERFECTIONIST, THE: LIFE AND DEATH IN HAUTE CUISINE (BOOK)

docs.abstract: William Grimes reviews book The Perfectionist: Life and Death in Haute Cuisine by Rudolph Chelminski; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The Perfectionist Life and Death in Haute Cuisine By Rudolph Chelminski 354 pages. Gotham Books. $27.50. On Feb. 24, 2003, a bulletin interrupted the 11 o'clock news on French television. Bernard Loiseau had been found dead in his home, a suicide at age 52. No one needed to ask who Bernard Loiseau was. The chef and owner of the three-star Côte d'Or, a restaurant in Burgundy, he was a media darling, an upbeat, tireless self-promoter whose big smile and bouncy personality made him a natural for television programs and splashy magazine features. With an adoring wife and three children, and an expanding empire -- three Paris bistros, a line of prepared foods -- he seemed to have it all, right down to the Legion of Honor, conferred by François Mitterrand, one of his biggest fans.
docs.snippet: Rudolph Chelminski's portrait of Bernard Loiseau is also a deeply informed guide to the last half century of French cuisine....
